citation.article-title: Thiocapsa halophila sp. nov., a new halophilic phototrophic purple sulfur bacterium.

p.s: Description of Thiocapsa halophila sp. nov.
Thiocapsa halophila (ha. lo'phi, la. Gr. n. halos, salt; Gr. adj. philos, loving; M.L. adj. halophila, salt- loving)
Cells spherical, 1.5-2.5 μm in diameter; aggregates of 2, 4 or more cells.
Multiplication by binary fission.
Gram-negative.
Cells non motile.
Color of suspension, purple-red.
Photosynthetic membrane system of the vesicular type.
Contains bacteriochlorophyll a and okenone as major carotenoid.
Phototrophic under anaerobic conditions in the light; chemoautotrophic and chemoorganotrophic under microaerobic conditions in the dark.
Electron donors for photoautotrophic growth: H2, hydrogen sulfide, elemental sulfur, sulfite and thiosulfate.
Globules of elemental sulfur are stored inside the cells.
In presence of sulfide and carbonate, acetate, pyruvate, lactate and fructose are photoassimilated.
Glycerol and glucose are poorly used.
Vitamin B12 is required.
Not capable of assimilatory sulfate reduction.
Optimum pH: 7.0.
pH range: 6.0 to 8.0.
Growth temperature: 20-30°C.
Salinity range between 3% and 20% NaCl; optimum salinity at 7% NaCl.
DNA base composition. 65.9-66.6
Habitat.
Reduced sediments in coastal saltern with salt deposits exposed to light.
Type strain.
Strain SG 3202 isolated from saltern in Camargue (France) and deposited with the DSM, German Collection of Microorganisms, number 6210.
